subject: RE: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: ... You are correct, but I actually meant that at runtime, my code does not know why your code threw an NPE. ... Off the top of my head I doubt that Jtest can
messageBody:
>-----Original Message-----
>From: Ilja Preu√ü [mailto:ilja.preuss@...]
>Sent: Wednesday, September 11, 2002 4:10 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: RE: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
>
>
>> The problem is that I don't know if there was a problem with
>> the input, the processing or something random. If your code
>> returns an IllegalArgumentException, then I have a much
>> better idea of the issues.
>
>If you are on the same team, you could ask him. Possibly you could even
>find out by simply looking at the code and/or the JUnit tests.

You are correct, but I actually meant that at runtime, my code does not know why your code threw an NPE.

>One point I find more critical is that invalid input should be
>fail-fast. If a method fails because you provided invalid input to a
>prior method call, such problems are really hard to find. Can
>JTest help
>with such issues?

Off the top of my head I doubt that Jtest can explicitly help with this, but if all of your exposed APIs are "hardened" or made robust enough to satisfy Jtest, then there is a good likelihood that invalid parameter data will be rejected sooner rather than later.

>Regards, Ilja

Simon
